metadata.synopsis: The player meets Balthazar, the necromancer, in his temporary command centre in the Shar temple. They find him at an altar, repairing one of his damaged undead, while other minions bustle around. Balthazar has been sent by Ketheric Thorm to recover Nightsong, but has been unable to clear a path to her vault. He decides to recruit the player, upon recognising them as tadpoled. The player can agree or decline, and can possibly persuade him to loan his flesh golem to aid their exploration.
metadata.how_to_trigger: goto -828; 8; -784 fight the shadowquakesthe door to baltazar is now open. Approach and talk to him.

27.speaker: Balthazar
27.text: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
27.context: CinematicNodeContext: Balthazar looks up from an altar repurposed as a surgical table of sorts. One of his undead warriors, damaged, lies upon it.NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.

83.speaker: Balthazar
83.text: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.

43.speaker: Balthazar
43.text: Though it's not all natural, is it? A touch of the divine... Most curious, for a True Soul.

54.speaker: Balthazar
54.text: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.

149.speaker: Player
149.text: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.

194.speaker: Player
194.text: Another True Soul was looking for you. Nere - I aided him in the Underdark.

17.speaker: Balthazar
17.text: Ah, it was you who pulled his sorry carcass from the rubble. You should have left him there.

273.speaker: Balthazar
273.text: The miserable worm tried to kill me, hoping to take all the glory of this mission for himself.

143.speaker: Balthazar
143.text: Dull, dull, dull. Nere was never cut out to be a True Soul - he's a very obedient corpse, though.

258.speaker: Balthazar
258.text: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?

197.speaker: Player
197.text: Balthazar, I presume? Z'rell sent me. She thinks you're in danger of failing your master.
197.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player received the Balthazar quest from Z'rell

204.speaker: Player
204.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player didn't receive  the Balthazar quest from Z'rell

255.speaker: Player
255.text: I fought a battle right under your nose - help would have been useful.

226.speaker: Player
226.text: I fought a battle right under your nose - whoever you are, some help would have been useful.

67.speaker: Balthazar
67.text: Do you truly expect your betters to sully their hands to aid you at every turn, True Soul? Such a poor grasp of hierarchy...

178.speaker: Player
178.text: True Soul? Bold of you, to assume I'm a comrade.

154.speaker: Player
154.text: Bold of you to assume I didn't destroy your skeletons deliberately.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: Naturally-born? That's a strange thing to hold against someone.

33.speaker: Balthazar
33.text: Not so. Womb births are such imprecise things... There's always room for improvement when it comes to the flesh.

170.speaker: Balthazar
170.text: My creations are more than a sum of their parts.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: Enough unpleasantries. You're Balthazar, yes? Z'rell sent me, to ensure you didn't fail your master.

114.speaker: Player
114.text: Your creations? Mindless undead minions, from what I've seen.

270.speaker: Balthazar
270.text: They are mere sketches compared to my masterwork - that would leave you in awe, should you be fortunate enough to bear witness.

222.speaker: Player
222.text: You're assuming I'm an ally. Unwise, perhaps.

175.speaker: Balthazar
175.text: Is it? I've seen inside your head, thanks to my troops. Besides, if you were an enemy, you'd be completely surrounded.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: I'm friendly. Z'rell sent me to make sure you weren't failing your master.
91.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player knows of Balthazar from Z'rell

131.speaker: Balthazar
131.text: Rubbish. Everything is at hand here - Z'rell merely envies the General's faith in me. I am in the midst of a grand strategy.

202.speaker: Balthazar
202.text: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.

122.speaker: Balthazar
122.text: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.

218.speaker: Player
218.text: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting.
121.context: InternalNodeContext: |Flag Needed|  for searching Balthazar's MRT quarters

229.speaker: Player
229.text: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?

263.speaker: Balthazar
263.text: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.

253.speaker: Balthazar
253.text: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.

37.speaker: Balthazar
37.text: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
31.context: InternalNodeContext: |Flag Needed|  for searching Balthazar's MRT quarters

97.speaker: Balthazar
97.text: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: I had Z'rell's permission - that good enough for you?
68.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if Z'rell briefed the player and they had instructions to look in Balthazar's room in Moonrise

162.speaker: Balthazar
162.text: Z'rell exceeds her authority. But fine, I'll overlook your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: I received permission. Take it up with your peers at Moonrise, if you have an issue.
73.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player did not have instructions to look in Balthazar's room in Moonrise

264.speaker: Balthazar
264.text: Liar. Liar and a waste of flesh. I'll see what I can salvage from you, after my creations are through with you.
264.context: NodeContext: Unconvinced, furious. Combat ensues afterwards

15.speaker: Player
15.text: Because I'll rip your tongue out, shove it down your throat, then stomp on your 'creations' until they are dirt beneath my feet.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: Touch me, and I'll strike you down with all of nature's fang and fury. Go ahead - try me.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: I wield the divine. I can use it to assist you, or send you screaming to the Fugue Plane. Your choice.

25.speaker: Player
25.text: Do it - unleash your creations. But they will not protect you from me - or my righteous fury.

216.speaker: Player
216.text: You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.

21.speaker: Balthazar
21.text: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
21.context: CinematicNodeContext: Squints at the player, considering, before speaking.NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.

129.speaker: Balthazar
129.text: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
129.context: NodeContext: Peeved at the intrusion, but also proud of his work

8.speaker: Balthazar
8.text: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
8.context: NodeContext: First sentence: dreamily waxing lyrcial about Nightsong. Second sentence: down to business.

99.speaker: Balthazar
99.text: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

80.speaker: Player
80.text: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.

243.speaker: Balthazar
243.text: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...

7.speaker: Balthazar
7.text: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: What do you need me to do?

182.speaker: Balthazar
182.text: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.

213.speaker: Balthazar
213.text: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
213.context: InternalNodeContext: Searched Balthazar's MRT quarters/mentioned Nightsong

24.speaker: Balthazar
24.text: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.

268.speaker: Balthazar
268.text: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

137.speaker: Shadowheart
137.text: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.

262.speaker: Player
262.text: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.

265.speaker: Balthazar
265.text: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
265.context: CinematicNodeContext: Reaches behind his back for the bell

85.speaker: Balthazar
85.context: CinematicNodeContext: Balthazar holds up a small bell  and gives it a short ring. The flesh golem looks at it and gurgles with interest.

173.speaker: Balthazar
173.text: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.

101.speaker: Balthazar
101.text: Flesh will remain here until called. Don't fear, he has very sharp hearing - I chose his ears myself. Now, get to work.

190.speaker: Player
190.text: Wait. It - he - is your brother?

125.speaker: Balthazar
125.text: In part, yes - my poor unborn twin. Mother always resented me for it - said I strangled him in the womb, if you can believe such tripe.

134.speaker: Balthazar
134.text: Besides, once I developed my powers, I fetched him from the graveyard and brought him back - gave him a new, better body. Alas, mother was... not pleased.

98.speaker: Balthazar
98.text: We're still close. She's in a jar on the shelf over there.
98.context: CinematicNodeContext: Cannot include shot of the jar - we cannot guarantee that it is still on the shelf

92.speaker: Balthazar
92.text: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!
92.context: NodeContext: Briefly confused, then angry (player has taken the jar containing parts of his dead mother)

188.speaker: Balthazar
188.text: Good. And keep your hands to yourself in future.
188.context: CinematicNodeContext: Item transfer gestureNodeContext: Cooling down (player has returned the jar containing his dead mother)

59.speaker: Player
59.text: No, I think I'll keep her.

195.speaker: Balthazar
195.text: I gave you a chance, mother-thief!

64.speaker: Player
64.text: What exactly will you be doing while I'm out risking myself?
64.context: InternalNodeContext: Question only available if the player hasn't yet agreed to help (for hasmet flow)

151.speaker: Balthazar
151.text: My creations need tending to - not that it's any of your concern.

44.speaker: Balthazar
44.text: This one's broken. He once tormented me as a youth, lifetimes ago. Now he serves me, forever.
44.context: CinematicNodeContext: Smiling fondly down at the damaged skeleton on the altarNodeContext: 'This guy used to pick on me. Now look at him'

66.speaker: Balthazar
66.text: No rest for you yet, Mikan. You will serve me until I am satisfied.
66.context: CinematicNodeContext: Leans down, whispers the line to the damaged skeleton, then straightens back upNodeContext: Whispered taunt. Mick-an

29.speaker: Player
29.text: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.

100.speaker: Balthazar
100.text: Go, then - you'll either come to your senses, or die in this place without me.

234.speaker: Balthazar
234.text: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.

224.speaker: Player
224.text: Fine. I'll see what I can do.

230.speaker: Player
230.text: There's always a choice. Like I can let you live, or not.

274.speaker: Balthazar
274.text: Go, then. You'll be back, once you've had another taste of Shar's hospitality.

152.speaker: Balthazar
152.text: You will obey - once you are reborn as one of my creations.

181.speaker: Player
181.text: Obey? No - I will smite you where you stand, necromancer.

4.speaker: Balthazar
4.text: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
4.context: CinematicNodeContext: Reaches behind his back for the bell

32.speaker: Balthazar
32.text: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.

141.speaker: Player
141.text: I'll see what I can do.

120.speaker: Balthazar
120.text: Do not fail me, or you can share in Mikan's fate.
120.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gestures at the broken skeleton on the altar beside himInternalNodeContext: This node if the Necromancer referred to Mikan beforeNodeContext: Mick-an

201.speaker: Balthazar
201.text: Do not fail me. If you do, you'll join the ranks of my creations, and be forced to try again.
201.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gestures at the broken skeleton on the altar beside himInternalNodeContext: This node if the Necromancer did not refer to Mikan before

10.speaker: Player
10.text: This sounds like your problem, not mine.

172.speaker: Balthazar
172.text: I think not. You seem a capable type, and I'll need to keep myself well-protected in this place.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: About the orthon in these ruins - friend or foe to you?

248.speaker: Balthazar
248.text: The devil is of no relevance to my goal. Besides, it seems you handled him well enough - I no longer hear that blasted singing of his.

244.speaker: Balthazar
244.text: Perhaps I will seek out his carcass, should I be afforded the opportunity. Surely there are some parts I could put to use...

247.speaker: Balthazar
247.text: Neither. That caterwauling beast is irrelevant as far as I'm concerned - unless he hampers my goals. In that case, consider him a foe, and act accordingly.

133.speaker: Player
133.text: Wrong - no part of you will remain here when I'm finished with you.

203.speaker: Player
203.text: I never said I was going to help. This is your problem.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: I think I'd rather exploit the Nightsong for myself - after I've gotten rid of you.

177.speaker: Balthazar
177.text: Promising flesh wasted on an idiot mind, I see. I'll salvage what parts I can from you.

146.speaker: Player
146.text: I think I'd rather exploit this relic - after I've gotten rid of you.

237.speaker: Balthazar
237.text: You are a waste of flesh. I'll see what I can salvage, after my creations are through with you.

171.speaker: Player
171.text: Sir, I am a jack-of-all-trades and a master of many. Our meeting was not by chance - you need me.

267.speaker: Player
267.text: You are a ship without a sail, necromancer. You need allies - you need me.

242.speaker: Player
242.text: Because I am magical powerhouse. You need me, and you know it.

246.speaker: Player
246.text: I outmatch you in both brains and magic - you need me.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.

86.speaker: Balthazar
86.text: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
86.context: CinematicNodeContext: Squints at the player, considering, before speaking.NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?

168.speaker: Balthazar
168.text: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
168.context: NodeContext: First sentence spoken as a reprimand, for not referring to Ketheric Thorm with due deferrence.

11.speaker: Balthazar
11.text: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.

109.speaker: Narrator
109.text: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*

212.speaker: Player
212.text: So you need my help - what would I have to do?

140.speaker: Player
140.text: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?

5.speaker: Balthazar
5.text: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

161.speaker: Balthazar
161.text: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.

225.speaker: Player
225.text: Jobs like this always go smoother when I know exactly what I'm looking for.

198.speaker: Player
198.text: A scout is little good if they don't know what to look for. What does this relic do?

250.speaker: Player
250.text: What are the properties of this relic, magical or otherwise? So I can be of better assistance, of course.

214.speaker: Player
214.text: I'm not the type to make a deal without the details. What exactly am I looking for?

42.speaker: Player
42.text: As much as I enjoy you flattering me, this isn't my problem.

232.speaker: Narrator
232.text: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.*

159.speaker: Player
159.text: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?

47.speaker: Balthazar
47.text: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...

150.speaker: Balthazar
150.text: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: Interesting - let's test that theory. Time to die, monster.

138.speaker: Balthazar
138.text: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: Balthazar - I heard of a monk by that name once. He died a long time ago.

65.speaker: Balthazar
65.text: He didn't seem very legendary when I took his name - naught but a pile of bones. Impressive tomb, though.

110.speaker: Balthazar
110.text: But enough idle chatter - keep to the matter at hand. You do know what's at stake here, yes?

165.speaker: Balthazar
165.text: Oh, him? Yes, I decided to take his name for myself after taking his rib bones. Suits me better, I think.

104.speaker: Player
104.text: The name Balthazar seems familar, but not as a servant of Ketheric Thorm. Where have you heard it before?

235.speaker: Narrator
235.text: *It comes back to you - Balthazar headed a monastic order that controlled a place called Amkethran, in the deserts of Calimshan... but he is long dead, from what you recall.*

19.speaker: Narrator
19.text: *The thought eludes you. Perhaps you saw a passing reference in some old tome.*

102.speaker: Player
102.text: The name Balthazar seems vaguely familar, but from where?

40.speaker: Player
40.text: You're sure you've read of a notable Balthazar before... But where?

116.speaker: Narrator
116.text: *You remember an ancient scroll rescued from an Amkethran monastery. It spoke of Balthazar, the monastic order's leader. Specifically, it recorded his death.*

252.speaker: Player
252.text: Let's assume I'm friendly. Who are you?

155.speaker: Player
155.text: I could break you quicker than you could squeak an order. Talk - who are you?

63.speaker: Player
63.text: Doesn't matter - I've already mapped out five escape routes. But I'll bite - who are you?

38.speaker: Balthazar
38.text: You are a True Soul - there is no excuse for you to not recognise your betters.

238.speaker: Balthazar
238.text: But never mind, your potential may outweigh your ignorance. I am Balthazar - Chief Advisor to General Thorm, and entrusted with a mission of utmost importance.

75.speaker: Balthazar
75.text: Do you know what is at stake here?

164.speaker: Player
164.text: I hunt and kill monsters - such threats mean nothing to me. Talk - who are you?

189.speaker: Player
189.text: You expect your words to spark fear - but I am past such things. Who are you?

124.speaker: Player
124.text: You didn't look deep enough. This will be your end, monster.

187.speaker: Player
187.text: Naturally-born? That's a strange thing to hold against someone.

245.speaker: Player
245.text: Naturally-born? I don't know if it's true, but that's a novel insult.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: Well, I'm not just a True Soul. I have some extraplanar help, so to speak.

223.speaker: Player
223.text: I'll be pleased when I separate your head from your shoulders, necromancer.

186.speaker: Player
186.text: You've fouled the name of mages long enough. I'll never let you leave this place alive, necromancer.

145.speaker: Balthazar
145.text: Such a... limited grasp of mortality. Idiot.

103.speaker: Balthazar
103.text: I said you'd be back. Reconsidered my proposition?

211.speaker: Player
211.text: Give me the bell. I'll see what I can do.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: All right, I'll help you find the Nightsong.
56.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player knows about Nightsong via Balthazar's research and previously revealed this to the necormancer.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: All right, I'll help you find the Nightsong - and yes, I know more about this 'relic' than you realise.
12.context: InternalNodeContext: This QN if the player knows about Nightsong via Balthazar's research, but didn't previously reveal it.

163.speaker: Balthazar
163.text: Been prying into my research, then? What a devious piece of flesh you are. Consider yourself lucky that I have use for you.
163.context: NodeContext: Displeased, but willing to let it go for the sake of the mission.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: All right, I'll help you find this relic.
93.context: InternalNodeContext: This question node if the player isn't aware of nightsong via Balthazar's research in MOO.

166.speaker: Player
166.text: What do you need of me?

60.speaker: Player
60.text: No, I just decided to kill you instead.

260.speaker: Balthazar
260.text: Kill me? Death is my ally, fool.

192.speaker: Balthazar
192.text: Not lost your nerve, I hope? I tend to remove those from my creations - too much fuss.

228.speaker: Player
228.text: I'll take that bell. It may prove useful.

148.speaker: Player
148.text: Balthazar - I heard of a monk by that name once. He died a long time ago.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: You could have warned me about the orthon that was lurking in this place.

34.speaker: Balthazar
34.text: I could have, but decided not to - all the better for judging your mettle.

136.speaker: Balthazar
136.text: That caterwauling beast is irrelevant as far as I'm concerned - unless he hampers my goals. In that case, consider him a foe, and act accordingly.
